problems.title: A  function that is discontinuous at every real number
problems.problem: Find an example of a function that is discontinuous at every real number.
problems.hint: • Consider the function which takes a constant value on rationals and constant value on irrationals.
problems.solution:
Consider the function $f: \mathbb{R} \rightarrow \mathbb{R} $ \[ f(x) = \begin{cases} 1, &\text{ if } x \in \mathbb{Q} ;\\ 0, &\text{ if } x \in \mathbb{R} \setminus \mathbb{Q} . \end{cases} \] We will show that the function is not continuous at any real number.
Let $a \in \mathbb{Q} $. We will show that $f$ is not continuous at $a$. Consider a sequence of irrational which converges to $a$. One possible sequence is \[ x_n = a + \frac{\sqrt{2}}{n}, \quad n \in \mathbb{N} . \] Note that for any $n \in \mathbb{N} $, \[ f(x_n) = f \left( a + \frac{\sqrt{2} }{n} \right) = 0. \] So the sequence $f(x_n) \rightarrow 0$ but $f(a) = 1$, thus the function is not continuous at any rational number.
Now let $a \in \mathbb{R} \setminus \mathbb{Q} $ and consider a sequence of rationals converging to $a$ (this can be done as $\mathbb{Q}$ is dense in $\mathbb{R} $). A way to construct the sequence is as follows. Without loss of generality assume that $a > 0$. Between $0$ and $a$, due to density of rationals in reals, there exists a rational number, say $q_1$. Similarly, get another rational number $q_2$ such that $0 < q_1 < q_2 < a$. In the similar way, we get a sequence of increasing rationals $0 < q_1 < q_2 < \dots < q_n < \dots < a$ which converges to $a$. Now to show that $f$ is discontinuous at $a$, note that \[ \lim_{n \to \infty} f(q_n) = \lim_{n \to \infty} 1 = 1, \] whereas, $f(a) = 0$. Thus, $f$ is not continuous at $a$. As $a$ was arbitrarily chosen irrational number, $f$ is not continuous at any irrational number.

Thus $f$ is discontinuous at every real number.

problems.title: f(x) = x^2 is not uniformly continuous on R
problems.problem: Prove that. $f(x) = x^2$ is uniformly continuous on $[0,1]$ but not uniformly continuous on $\mathbb{R} $.
problems.hint:
• A continuous function on a compact set is uniformly continuous.
  • As $x$ is increasing, the graph becomes more straight and hence in the functional value it takes a big jump, which suggests not uniform continuous on $\mathbb{R} $.
problems.solution:
To show that $f(x) = x^2$ is uniformly continuous, let $\varepsilon > 0 $ be given. We need to find $\delta = \delta (\varepsilon ) > 0$ such that for any any $x,y \in [0,1]$ \[ |x - y| < \delta (\varepsilon ) \implies |f(x) - f(y)| < \epsilon . \] Consider \begin{align*} \vert f(x) - f(y) \vert & = \vert x^2 - y^2 \vert \\ & = \vert (x-y)(x+y) \vert \\ & = \vert x-y \vert \cdot \vert x+y \vert \\ & \leq \vert x - y \vert \left( \vert x \vert + \vert y \vert \right) \\ & \leq 2 \vert x - y \vert . \end{align*} Choose $\delta (\varepsilon ) = \frac{\varepsilon }{6}$. If $\vert x - y \vert < \frac{\varepsilon}{6} $, then \begin{align*} \vert f(x) - f(y) \vert \leq 2 \vert x-y \vert < 2 \frac{\varepsilon }{6} = \frac{\varepsilon }{3} < \varepsilon . \end{align*} Thus, the function is uniformly continuous on $[0,1]$. Note that the same proof can be adopt for any bounded set, that is, the function is uniformly continuous on any bounded set.
Now to see that the function is not uniformly continuous on $\mathbb{R} $, to the contrary assume that $x^2$ is uniformly continuous on $\mathbb{R} $. So for any $\varepsilon > 0$, we can find $\delta (\varepsilon ) > 0$ such that \[ \vert x - y \vert < \delta (\varepsilon ) \implies \vert f(x) - f(y) \vert < \varepsilon . \] Choose $\varepsilon = 1$, so there exists $\delta = \delta(\varepsilon ) > 0$ such that \[ \vert x - y \vert < \delta (\varepsilon ) \implies \vert f(x) - f(y) \vert < 1 . \] By Archimedean property, choose $n \in \mathbb{N} $ such that $\delta > \frac{1}{n}$. Take $x = n$ and $y = n + \frac{\delta}{2} $, then \begin{align*} \vert x - y \vert & = \left\vert n - n + \frac{\delta}{2} \right\vert = \left\vert \frac{\delta }{2} \right\vert > \frac{1}{2n} > \varepsilon , \end{align*} a contradiction. Thus, $f(x) = x^2$ is not uniformly continuous on $\mathbb{R} $.

problems.title: NBHM 2005 - Infinite sum of functional value
problems.problem:
Let $f: [0,1] \to  \mathbb{R} $ be a continuous function. Then find 
    \[
        \lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{1}{n}\sum_{k=0}^{n} f \left( \frac{k}{n}. \right) 
    \]
problems.hint:
• Since $f$ is continuous, it is Riemann integrable.
  • Use definite integral as a limit of sum.
problems.solution:
Since $f$ is continuous on the closed interval $[0,1]$, it is Riemann integrable on $[0,1]$. We need to find the sum \[ \frac{1}{n}\sum_{k=0}^{n} f\left(\frac{k}{n}\right). \] This sum differs from the standard Riemann sum \[ \sum_{k=0}^{n-1} f\left(\frac{k}{n}\right)\frac{1}{n} \] only by the additional term $\frac{1}{n}f(1)$.
Thus we can write \begin{align*} & \frac{1}{n}\sum_{k=0}^{n} f\left(\frac{k}{n}\right) = \sum_{k=0}^{n-1} f\left(\frac{k}{n}\right)\frac{1}{n} + \frac{1}{n}f(1) \\ \implies & \lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{1}{n}\sum_{k=0}^{n} f\left(\frac{k}{n}\right) = \lim_{n \to \infty} \left[ \sum_{k=0}^{n-1} f\left(\frac{k}{n}\right)\frac{1}{n} + \frac{1}{n}f(1) \right] \\ & \kern 2.85cm = \lim_{n \to \infty} \sum_{k=0}^{n-1} f\left(\frac{k}{n}\right)\frac{1}{n} + \lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{1}{n}f(1) \tag{1} \\ & \kern 2.85cm = \int_0^1 f(x) \mathrm{d} x + 0. \end{align*} Note that (1) is valid because $f$ is Riemann integrable and hence both the limit exists. Therefore, \[ \lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{1}{n}\sum_{k=0}^{n} f\left(\frac{k}{n}\right) = \int_0^1 f(x)\,dx. \]

problems.title: An upper bound is greater than or equals to lower bounds
problems.problem: Let $E$ be a nonempty subset of an ordered set $(X, \preccurlyeq)$. Suppose $\alpha $ is a lower bound of $E$ and $\beta $ is an upper bound of $E$. Prove that $\alpha \preccurlyeq \beta $.
problems.hint: • $\alpha$ is a lower bound of $E$ if $\alpha \preccurlyeq x$ for any $x \in E$ and $\beta $ is an upper bound of $E$ if $x \preccurlyeq \beta $ for any $x \in E$.
problems.solution: As $E \neq \varnothing $, take $x_0 \in E$. Since $\alpha $ is a lower bound of $E$, so for $x_0 \in E$ we have \begin{equation}\label{eq:26Jan2026-1} \alpha \preccurlyeq x_0. \end{equation} Since $\beta $ is an upper bound of $E$, so we have \begin{equation}\label{eq:26Jan2026-2} x_0 \preccurlyeq \beta . \end{equation} Combining \eqref{eq:26Jan2026-1} and \eqref{eq:26Jan2026-2}, we get \[ \alpha \preccurlyeq x_0 \preccurlyeq \beta \implies \alpha \preccurlyeq \beta . \]

problems.title: Uniform convergence of the series pi/2 - arctan(n^p ( 1 + x^2))
problems.problem:
Let $p>1$. Show that the series 
    \[
        \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \left[ \frac{\pi }{2} - \arctan \left[ n^p (1 + x^2) \right]  \right] 
    \] 
    converges uniformly on $\mathbb{R} $.
problems.hint:
• For $x > 0$, recall that $\arctan x + \arctan \frac{1}{x} = \frac{\pi}{2} $.
  • For $x>0$, $\arctan x < x$.
  • Use Weierstrass $M$-test.
problems.solution:
Recall that for $x > 0$, \[ \arctan x + \arctan \frac{1}{x} = \frac{\pi}{2}. \] This implies, for any $x \in \mathbb{R} $ \begin{equation}\label{eq:02Feb2026-1} 0 < \frac{\pi}{2} - \arctan \left[ n^p (1 + x^2) \right] = \arctan \frac{1}{n^p(1 + x^2)}. \end{equation}
Consider the function $f(x) = x - \arctan x$ for $x > 0$. Since \[ f'(x) = 1 - \frac{1}{1 + x^2} = \frac{x^2}{1 + x^2} > 0, \] so $f$ is a strictly increasing function on $(0, \infty )$. Thus, for $x > 0$ \begin{equation}\label{eq:02Feb2026-2} x - \arctan x > 0 \implies x > \arctan x. \end{equation}
Now the inequality \eqref{eq:02Feb2026-1} simplified to \begin{align*} \frac{\pi}{2} - \arctan [n^p ( 1 + x^2)] < \frac{1}{n^p(1 + x^2)} \leq \frac{1}{n^p} \end{align*} for all $x \in \mathbb{R} $. Since $p> 1$, so the series $\sum_{n} \frac{1}{n^p} $ is convergent. Now the conclusion follows from Weierstrass $M$-test.
